definition: to hold/to contain/to grasp/to take hold of/handle/particle marking the following noun as a direct object/classifier for objects with handle/classifier for small objects: handful
to perform magic/to do magic tricks/prestidigitation

sentences.english: Feints and stratagems are the stuff of chess.
sentences.chinese: 佯装与计谋都是下象棋常耍的把戏。

sentences.english: On the one hand, I can see that this is a pretty cool gadget.
sentences.chinese: 从这方面讲，我认为它是一个相当出色的小把戏。

sentences.english: The lap-dog knew many tricks, and was a great favourite with his master.
sentences.chinese: 哈巴狗却会很多的鬼把戏，深得主人的宠爱。

sentences.english: You can't teach an old dog new tricks.
It's a behavior trick for younger kids.
sentences.chinese: 这对你的小小孩儿来说是个“小把戏”。

sentences.english: It was a 11)dirty trick, but it killed old Phoebe.
sentences.chinese: 这实在是种卑鄙把戏，可差点儿把老菲比笑死。

sentences.english: You can always go trick-or-treating during the afternoon or to the mall.
sentences.chinese: 你可以一直在下午或商业街上耍那唬人的把戏。

sentences.english: You go with those juggler, all went to some place?
sentences.chinese: 你跟那些耍把戏的走了，都到了些什么地方呢？

sentences.english: This year, there were no tricks and no serious injuries.
sentences.chinese: 今年的比赛没有骗人把戏，也没有人重伤。

sentences.english: My dead dog, Bobby, doesn't do tricks anymore.
sentences.chinese: 我的死狗博比再也不能玩那些小把戏了。

sentences.english: This little trick is like a mini reflexology session.
sentences.chinese: 这项小把戏就像是种迷你反射疗法。

sentences.english: Lester had been famous among the line workers for a magic trick.
sentences.chinese: 莱斯特在一线员工中以一种魔术把戏而闻名。

sentences.english: The proud look on my 4-year-old son’s face when he learns a new skill.
sentences.chinese: 4岁儿子学会新把戏时的，他脸上的自豪感。

sentences.english: They cunningly played the game of sham peace.
sentences.chinese: 他们狡滑地玩弄假和平的把戏。

definition: the trick of injuring oneself to gain the enemy's confidence/CL:條|条[tiao2]
to play with/to wield/to act (cool etc)/to display (a skill, one's temper etc)
to play with/to engage in/to resort to/to dally with
lit. dress up as God, play the devil (idiom); fig. to mystify/to deceive people/to scam
deliberately mystifying/to make sth unnecessarily complicated
to act in a play/to put on a play
to play the fool (idiom)/to feign madness
